Award.AbstractNarration:
During the period June 13-16, 2016, Harvard University will host a conference in pure mathematics on the theme of L-functions and Arithmetic. The purpose of the conference is to gather together leading experts and young researchers to discuss recent developments on the connections between analytic and algebraic aspects of number theory and arithmetic geometry. Such research has applications to cyber security, through cryptography, and to some aspects of coding theory. A significant portion of NSF funding will be used to fund the travel and housing of junior participants (e.g. graduate students and postdocs).

Over the four days of the conference there will be seventeen lectures by experts in number theory and arithmetic geometry. The conference program will focus on recent developments in (commutative and noncommutative) Iwasawa theory; the construction of new Euler systems for Galois representations; Stark's conjecture and the equivariant Tamagawa number conjecture; p-adic interpolation of modular forms, Selmer groups, and L-values; and recent breakthroughs in the study of average behaviors of class groups, Selmer groups, and Mordell-Weil groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to host a major research conference entitled "L-functions and Arithmetic" in honor of Karl Rubin's 60th birthday. The conference was held June 13-16, 2016 at Harvard University. The conference's main theme was to explore the links between special values of motivic L-functions and the arithmetic/cohomological invariants of the motives in question. The object of the conference was to bring the experts in the field up to date with the developments, and to give graduate students and postdocs an opportunity to break into this quickly evolving field. The conference drew around 250 registered participants from around the world. There were 16 one hour talks over the four days of the conference. The NSF grant funds went towards travel and lodging for participants and advertising materials. The more junior participants were given ample opportunity to interact with the seasoned researchers in the field.

A significant outcome of this conference is a renewed emphasis in "statistics regarding L-function special values” and this has already shown itself in a series of subsequent conferences for example the workshop May 11-12, 2017 held at Harvard that Karl Rubin and Barry Mazur organized using some of the remaining funds from the conference. The purpose of this workshop was to get small groups of specialists in number theory to pool their talents, experience and resources in order to advance the study of what might broadly be described as (aspects of) statistics relevant to polynomial equations and their solutions in rational integers.

This, of course, has been a focus for mathematicians since the time of Diophantus (3rd century AD). There are various ways of gaining experience in problems of this sort. The first is what may thought of as the primary mode of study: to deal with the arithmetic structure(s) involved? e.g., as in a famous theorem of Faltings that guarantees that there are only finitely many solutions (in rational integers) to a large and interesting class of polynomials in two variables—more specifically: if C is an algebraic curve of genus > 1 defined over a number field K, there are only finitely K-rational points on C. A somewhat different direction is to understand as closely as possible the behavior of L-functions—these being analytic functions L(A, χ? s) that conjecturally convey information about the existence (or nonexistence) of (infinitely many) rational points on A (an abelian variety). Even though the link between these two approaches is conjectural, it is extremely useful to gain statistical experience from the latter approach, to develop detailed expectations about the nature of rational points. It is this latter direction that was the focus of our workshop, which had quite a number of consequences following it. 

The work in the workshop described above will continue in a four day workshop organized, again, by Karl Rubin and Barry Mazur, at Les Treilles (France) in July, 2018. This will consist of Karl Rubin, Barry Mazur, Bernard Teissier, and ten young researchers (largely postdoctoral, or graduate students) . The main thrust of this upcoming workshop will not consist in formal talks, but rather informal discussions, question and answer sessions, and working sessions. The immediate aim will be to discuss heuristics and results—and make computations—in the arithmetic of elliptic curves over number fields and function fields? and to work on various related issues. A tentative list of topics is below, but this is very tentative since the activity of the workshop will be principally working in groups rather than having a fixed schedule, the opening meeting will be an organizing session, where in communal discussion, we will organize some of the questions to be focused on and discussed, either in large or small groups: 

  1. Distributions connected to modular symbol values, and issues related to the vanishing (at the central point s = 1) of L-functions.
  2. Geometric structures that give infinite families of cyclic field extensions over which a given elliptic curve obtains new rational points. 
  3. The function field analogues of these problems.
  4. Conjectures regarding the qualitative behavior of Mordell-Weil in big abelian extensions. 

That this general theme is intensely focused on at present (by the wider number theory research community) can be seen by the existence of at least two other conferences on the topic this summer (one by the Simons Foundation and another at Oberwohlfach).
